title: Smart virtual agent
content:
End users can chat with the smart virtual agent in Service Portal in natural language. The smart virtual agent combines Rasa with IDOL to understand their intentions and find the most matched intent predefined to provide either related answers or catalog offerings as responses. Rasa natural language understanding (NLU) is an open source natural language processing (NLP) tool for intent classification and user option extraction. The smart virtual agent uses Rasa as a set of high level APIs for building your own language parser with existing NLP and machine learning libraries. However, the classification algorithm only manages limited data volume. When an end user's question isn't understood by Rasa, the virtual agent utilizes IDOL and leverages the bigger index data volume in IDOL to provide cognitive search against the end user's question. The following diagram illustrates the smart virtual agent workflow:

  1. When an end user enters an issue or a question, the smart virtual agent matches the input to an appropriate intent based on the training sentences predefined in that intent.
  2. The smart virtual agent follows the entitlement rules defined in Access Control List (ACL), and then suggests intents based on the catalog offering and the KM articles that are eligible to this end user's profile. The smart virtual agent's response can prompt the end user either for more information to continue the conversation or to just end the conversation.

Enable the smart virtual agent

Helm deployment

To enable the Smart Virtual Agent for an on-premises suite deployment, follow these Helm deployment steps:

  1. Log in to the bastion node or master node.
  2. List all Helm releases. 
    helm list -A
  3. Retrieve your custom sma-values.yaml file: 
    helm get values sma -n itsma-eks > sma-values.yaml
  4. Edit the YAML file: 
    vi sma-values.yaml
    1. In the file, navigate to global > services.
    2. Set VA deployment to true.
  5. Verify the changes with a dry run: 
    helm upgrade sma esm-<release-tag>.tgz -n itsma-eks -f sma-values.yaml --dry-run
  6. Apply the changes: 
    helm upgrade sma esm-<release-tag>.tgz -n itsma-eks -f sma-values.yaml
  7. Check the upgrade status: 
    helm history sma -n itsma-eks
  8. Verify that Virtual Agent pods are running: 
    kubectl get pods -n itsma-eks | grep -i virtual
  9. If the upgrade fails, roll back to the previous revision: 
    helm rollback sma -n itsma-eks <REVISION>

Cloud deployment

Follow these steps to enable the smart virtual agent if your suite is deployed in the cloud:

  1. Log in to a control plane node as root or a sudo user, and run the following command to get the virtual agent pod status:
    kubectl get deployment -n <namespace> | grep virtual
    You can get the status for the following services:
    • virtual-agent-admin-ui
    • virtual-agent-nlu
    • virtual-agent-bot-engine
  2. Run the following command one by one to scale up the virtual agent pods: 
    kubectl scale deployment virtual-agent-admin-ui -n <namespace> --replicas=1
    kubectl scale deployment virtual-agent-nlu -n <namespace> --replicas=1
    kubectl scale deployment virtual-agent-bot-engine -n <namespace> --replicas=1
  3. Wait a few minutes and run the following command again to check if the pods are running with the status of 1/1. kubectl get deployment -n <namespace> | grep virtual
  4. If the pods are running, log in to Service Management, from the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Application Settings. Navigate to Enable smart virtual agent, select On. The smart virtual agent is part of the standard tenant life cycle management. For example, when you synchronize a development tenant to a production tenant, the virtual agent settings, intents, and user options on the development tenant are synchronized as well. Another example is, when you create, delete, or clone a tenant, the virtual agent settings, intents, and user options on this tenant are created, deleted, or cloned as well.

Configure the smart virtual agent

Follow these steps to configure the settings for a smart virtual agent:

  1. Select Administration > Configuration > AI Studio > Virtual Agent.

    Tips: The system may display a 503 error here because the smart virtual agent isn't enabled yet. It may take a while for the smart virtual agent to be enabled.

  2. Click the Configurations tab.
  3. In the Name field, enter a name for the smart virtual agent.

  4. Click the current avatar, and then browse for another photo that's saved on your computer. Select your new photo and then click Open. Alternatively, double-click the new photo. The system displays the new avatar automatically.

    The default avatar is  . The supported image types include *.jpg, *.png, and *.gif. The maximum file size is 2 MB and the recommended image dimension is 200x200 px.

    To remove this avatar, hover your mouse over the avatar and then click  .

  5. In the Greeting words field, type one or more greeting sentences for the smart virtual agent.
  6. Type a number in the Number of Intent suggestion attempts field to specify the smart virtual agent's maximum rounds of intent confirmation queries. For example, if a user selects No in a prompt provided by the smart virtual agent, the smart virtual agent may send another response back and prompt the end user for more information to continue the conversation. This back-and-forth process repeats in a cadence as you defined in this field.
  7. Type a decimal value between 0 and 1 in the Intent matching threshold field. The value of 0 is the slackest intent matching, whereas 1 represents the exactest matching.
  8. In the Information security tips field, type one or more security tips that may gain a user's attention. The system displays these sentences on top of the user's message input field when a conversation starts.
  9. Click Save to save your settings.

Manage user options

The smart virtual agent uses user options to parse parameters from user inputs. You need to define a corresponding user option for any important data you want to get from a user's request.

A user option consists of the following two main components:

  • User option name: The name of the user option.
  • Values: Defines the real world options for user selection in a chat.

Add a new user option

Follow these steps to add a new user option:

  1. Select Administration > Configuration > AI Studio > Virtual Agent.
  2. Click the User options tab to open the user options list.
  3. Click New to open the New user option page.
  4. Type a name for the new user option in the User option name field.

  5. Click ADD DEFINITION to add the value options to this user option. You can provide value and display name for each definition.

    Option Description
    Value

    The value of a definition. If the user option record is mapped to a user option in an offering or a field in a request, each value here must exactly match each user option item name or each field value name defined in Studio.

    This release only supports simple user option including the String, List, and Boolean types.
    Display name The string that's used for user selection during the runtime chat.
  6. Click Save to save the definition. To remove a definition, click .
  7. Add more definitions as necessary, and then click Save to save the user option.

Remove a user option

Follow these steps to remove a user option:

  1. Select a user option record on the User options tab page, and then click Delete. Alternatively, click on the user option to be removed.
    The system opens the Delete Confirmation dialog.
  2. Click DELETE to confirm.

Manage intents

An intent is basically a conversation rule that maps end user input to actions and responses of the smart virtual agent. In each intent, you can define examples of user inputs that can trigger the intent, what to extract from the input, and how to respond.

An intent consists of three main components that allow you to map what a user inputs to what a smart virtual agent responds with. These components include the following:

  • Intent name: The name of the intent.
  • Training sentences: Examples of what users can say to match a particular intent.
  • Action: Defines how relevant information is extracted from user inputs. You can use parameters as input into other logic, such as looking up information, carrying out a task, or returning a closing message.

Add new intents automatically

You may have an empty intent list in your system at the very beginning. To quickly add a list of intents, click Automatic Learning on the Intents tab page to automatically generate the intents for the smart virtual agent. If an error message "Request failed with status code 504" prompts after you click this button, click OK, wait a while, and then refresh the page, the learning process continues automatically. Here are some details about how this function works:

  1. The algorithm firstly searches and groups the user requests by the offerings, and then sorts the results to pick out the most popular offerings that have at least two related requests.

  2. The algorithm filters out the requests whose descriptions contain less than three words.

    Now the remaining offerings are qualified for automatic learning. Each offering has at least two related requests, and the description of each request has at least three words.

  3. The system automatically generates intents linked to these offerings. In each intent, the system generates the training sentences based on the descriptions of the most popular user requests and the display labels of the linked offerings, and then attaches an existing Service Catalog offering as an entity to the intent. You need to manually enable these intents.
If you click Automatic Learning multiple times, the system compares the intent names and will not overwrite the same intents that are existent.

Add a new intent manually

Follow these steps to add a new intent manually:

  1. Select Administration > Configuration > AI Studio > Virtual Agent.
  2. Click the Intents tab to open the intents list.
  3. Click New to open the New intent page.
  4. In the Intent name field, type a name for the intent. 

  5. (Optional) Turn on the Recommend the intent in the virtual agent's greetings option. The smart virtual agent includes this intent as one of the articles, news, or offerings in the greeting dialog when an end user starts a chat.

    In the greeting dialog, the smart virtual agent recommends up to three options for each type in the list. These types include Question, News, Article, and Offering.

  6. (Optional) Type a question in the Intent confirmation message field. The smart virtual agent displays this question to a user when the current intent is open. For example, Do you want to request a new PC?.

    If you leave this field blank, the smart virtual agent uses the intent name instead.

  7. Add multiple training sentences. The system requires at least one training sentence.

    Training sentences are collections of possible questions that an end user may ask when meeting a problem. You need to define multiple training sentences within an intent so that your smart virtual agent can recognize a greater variety of user input. The more variations added to training sentences, the better a smart virtual agent understands the end user's question.

    You can perform the following tasks:

    • Add a training sentence:
      Type a training sentence in the blank field, and then press Enter.
    • Edit a training sentence:
      Click a training sentence to edit, and then click the save button to save the changes.
    • Remove a training sentence:
      Click to remove a training sentence.

  8. Specify actions.

    Action refers to the smart virtual agent's solution to the intent. An action defines how the smart virtual agent processes the intent.

    The system provides two action modes and you can use the toggle key to switch from Entity link mode to Conversation mode.

    In the Entity link mode, you can attach an entity to the intent without additional configurations. Follow these steps:

    1. Click Attach an entity. The system opens the Attach an entity dialog.
    2. Filter or search for the entities.
    3. Select an entity, and then click ATTACH.
      Depending on your selection, the smart virtual agent either displays an article or opens a Support/Service Request based on the Catalog offerings when using the current intent.

    In the Conversation mode, you can perform the following tasks:

    • Define an action in the text field:
      An intent triggers a support request or a service request based on the scripts defined in this field. Note that:
      • The action name must be submit_offering_request.
      • Action parameters define the fields used in a request record. Make sure these parameters comply with the established business rules for handling requests. See Request flows.
      • Use meaningful English names for action parameters and avoid special characters like slashes (/), percentages (%), and spaces.
      See the following example of a JSON code snippet to configure the action. 
      {
  "name": "submit_offering_request",
  "parameters": {
    "Urgency": "${affect}",
    "Description": "${description}",
    "offering_id": "12201",
    "user_options": [
      {
        "name": "HomeLocation_c",
        "value": "${homeLocation}"
      },
      {
        "name": "OfficePhone_c",
        "value": "${officePhone}"
      }
    ],
    "PreferredContactMethod": "${contactMethod}"
  }
}
      The following image illustrates the user option mapping:

      The following table shows the sample properties and the descriptions.
      Property Example Description
      name submit_offering_request The action name.
      Urgency ${affect} The urgency level of this Service Request.
      Description ${description} The business justification field on a Service Request form.
      offering_id "12201" The offering ID in your Service Management system.
      user_options [{ "name": "HomeLocation_c",
      "value": "${homeLocation}"},
      { "name": "OfficePhone_c",
      "value": "${OfficePhone}"}]

      The array of objects for user options defined in this service offering. Each entry is an object for a specific user option. The name is the user option name, and you can find the name from the Catalog Management. The value is the parameter name preceded by a $.

      This release only supports simple user options. This release doesn't support dependent user option.
      PreferredContactMethod ${contactMethod} The Preferred contact method field on a Request form.

      However, the scripts in the action text field are optional. If you leave this text field blank, the smart virtual agent returns the closing messages as you defined to the end user. In this case, you must define a closing message.

    • Add a parameter:
      Click Add a parameter to add a new parameter. The following table shows the fields and the descriptions.
      Field Description
      Required Select the check box to mark this parameter as mandatory.
      Parameter name Type a name for the parameter.
      Virtual agent says

      Click Edit virtual agent says to specify the prompts. The smart virtual agent will use the prompts as questions during a chat.

      If you add multiple prompts for a parameter, the smart virtual agent will use these prompts randomly.
      Answer option type

      Select a user option from the drop-down list to associate the parameter with a user option. There is a system built-in user option named @sys.any that can be used to represent the string type of data such as "description" in requests.
    • Remove a parameter:
      Select the parameter to be removed, and then click the X icon.
    • Adjust the parameter sequence:
      Hover over a parameter, and then adjust its sequence by drag-and-drop.
    • Add or remove a closing message:
      The closing message is the smart virtual agent's final response in a chat session which is classified to the current intent. Click ADD CLOSING MESSAGE to add a new closing message to the current intent. You can use parameter values such as ${value} in the closing message.
      To remove a closing message, click the X icon on the right.
  9. Click Save to save the intent.
You can create up to 300 intents. For each intent, you can add up to 20 training sentences. There's also a limit for the total number of training sentences: 1000 for East Asian languages (Japanese, Simplified Chinese, and Korean), and 2400 for other languages. A suite administrator can change the default limit for total number of training sentences.

Disable an intent

To disable an intent, open an intent record on the Intents tab page, and then deselect the Enabled check box. After you disable an intent, the smart virtual agent no longer maps the user input to the actions and responses defined in this intent.

To enable an intent, select the Enabled check box.

After you enable or disable intents, return to the Intents tab page and then click Train so that the smart virtual agent can learn from your revision.

Remove an intent

Follow these steps to remove an intent:

  1. Select an intent record on the Intents tab page, and then click Delete. Alternatively, click on the intent.
    The system opens the Delete Confirmation dialog.
  2. Click DELETE to confirm.

Train an intent

After you edit intents, click Train on the Intents tab page so that the smart virtual agent can learn from your revision. After training, the smart virtual agent can chat with end users based on intents.

If the training fails, one possible cause is your hardware doesn't support AVX instructions. For details, see Smart virtual agent fails to perform training because the CPU doesn't support AVX.

The Train button is disabled if the number of enabled intents is smaller than 2.

Export and import

You can export and import the intents within the same suite version.

Click Export on the Intents tab page to export the settings of the smart virtual agent to a *.json file, which includes all intents, user options, and configurations. This *.json file can be used for backing up the smart virtual agent or transferring the smart virtual agent from one tenant to another.

To import and restore the smart virtual agent's settings, click Import on the Intents tab page and then click UPLOAD to select the exported *.json file. The entity IDs in the intents are updated to the offering IDs in the target tenant automatically, if there are no corresponding offerings in the target tenant, the entity IDs are left empty, you need to link them manually.

Multi-language support in one tenant

You can enter intents, user options, training sentences, and configurable messages in different languages, by clicking the  button next to the corresponding field. After you provide multilingual training sentences for a specific intent, go to the Intents tab and click Train.

The languages supported by the smart virtual agent are listed in Language support. End users can chat with the smart virtual agent in their preferred language. The smart virtual agent can automatically detect the language for intent prediction. If the detection fails, the agent will respond in the language specified in the end user's profile.

The configurable messages include greeting messages, security tips, confirmation messages, and closing messages. When end users launch the smart virtual agent chat window, the configurable messages and the intents list will be shown in the language set in the end user's profile.

Smart virtual agent configuration use case

This use case guides you to add one demonstration intent for updating the end user's personal information. Follow these sample steps:

  1. Add the contactMethod user option as shown in the following screenshot:

    This user option record is mapped to a field in a request, and each value here must exactly match each field value name defined in Studio. Here is a sample configuration in Service Management:

  2. Create a new intent, and then type an intent name, an intent confirmation message, and some training sentences as required. If you want to type in other languages, click the ellipsis button    and enter texts into your selected field. See the following screenshot as an example:

  3. Add the following scripts to the Action text field:

    {
  "name": "submit_offering_request",
  "parameters": {
    "Description": "${description}",
    "offering_id": "12201",
    "user_options": [
      {
        "name": "HomeLocation_c",
        "value": "${homeLocation}"
      },
      {
        "name": "OfficePhone_c",
        "value": "${officePhone}"
      }
    ],
    "PreferredContactMethod": "${contactMethod}"
  }
}

    Where:

    • Id 12201 is the ID for the service offering Change personal details in Service Management.
    • Description is displayed as the Business justification field on the Service Request form. The value ${description} is defined in the parameter section.

    • User_options contains two user options that are defined in the Change personal details service offering, and the value of ${homeLocation} and ${officePhone} are defined in the parameter section. They are the parameter names preceded by $. See the following screenshot as a sample configuration in Service Management:

    • PreferredContactMethod is displayed as the Preferred contact method field on the Service Request form. The value $contactmethod is defined in the parameter section.
  4. Add parameters and closing messages as shown in the following screenshot:
     

    Set the description parameter as required, and then click Edit virtual agent says. In the Prompts for the description parameter dialog, type Why did you move?. Set the answer option type to @sys.any so as to represent the end user's inputs, which is the string type of data.

    Set the contactMethod parameter as required, and then click Edit virtual agent says. In the Prompts for the description parameter dialog, type If we need to verify anything, what's the best way for HR to contact you?. Set the answer option type to contactMethod so that the system associates the parameter with a user option.

    Set the smart virtual agent says to What is your new address? for the homeLocation parameter, and then set the virtual agent says to Did you change your number as well? Let me know your new number and I'll update that as well. for the officePhone parameter.

  5. Click Train to perform training after you add the user options and intents. The system will notify you when the training is completed.

  6. Switch to Service Portal to start a chat with the smart virtual agent.

    Click Yes, and then type a reason as the smart virtual agent prompts.

    Click either email or phone to continue. The next two questions are optional, and you can either provide answers or ignore them. The virtual agent will then submit a service request for you. You can click the request link to view the detail of the ticket. After your contact information is updated in the system, the virtual agent prompts that your request is resolved.
